DOC.brief_summary: Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) is the most common pathogen encountered in infections associated with orthopedic surgery. StaphVAXÂ® is a bivalent S. aureus types 5 and 8 vaccine which contains the purified capsular polysaccharides that have been implicated as a major factor in the invasiveness of S. aureus. Immunoprophylaxis by vaccinating against S. aureus prior to surgery could provide sufficient antibody concentrations during surgery and the wound healing period so as to decrease the risk of S. aureus infection. This study aims to demonstrate the immunogenicity and safety of a single dose of StaphVAX in patients who are candidates for orthopedic surgery.
DOC.brief_title: StaphVAX Immunogenicity and Safety in Orthopaedic Joint Surgery
DOC.criteria: Age 18 years or older Candidate for knee or hip replacement Expectation of protocol compliance Negative pregnancy test, where appropriate Known S. aureus infection in the prior 3 months Infection in the prior 2 weeks Known HIV infection Immunomodulatory drugs Malignancy (other than basal cell or squamous cell carcinoma, carcinoma in situ of the cervix, or early prostate cancer) Hypersensitivity to components of StaphVAX
